word.entryDescription: to turn in the right/left direction
word.entryExample: Turn right and go straight on until you get to the road, then turn left

word.entryDescription: to make you feel sick or upset
word.entryExample: This sight turned my stomach.

word.entryDescription: to turn a switch on a device, e.g. radio, oven, etc so that it produces more sound, heat, etc
word.entryExample: I'll turn up the volume and listen to some music on my headphones while I work.

word.entryDescription: (for someone or something that has not been seen for a while) to appear unexpectedly
word.entryExample: We'd arranged to meet at 8 p.m., but he didn't turn up, so I tried calling him.

word.entryDescription: the number 12
word.entryExample: I always eat my lunch at twelve.

word.entryDescription: the number 20
word.entryExample: It takes twenty minutes to get here by train.

word.entryDescription: a small thin piece of wood which grows from a branch
word.entryExample: We need a few twigs to start the fire.

word.entryDescription: a brother or sister born at the same time as you
word.entryExample: They look the same because they are identical twins.

word.entryDescription: another name for a tornado
word.entryExample: The wind around the outside of a twister is whirling extremely fast.

word.entryDescription: the number 2
word.entryExample: She has two sisters.

word.entryDescription: to type some work on a keyboard
word.entryExample: Sam had to type up his report more than once.

word.entryDescription: not nice to look at
word.entryExample: The monster is very ugly!

word.entryDescription: a thing you hold over your head to protect yourself from the rain
word.entryExample: Take an umbrella in case it rains.

word.entryDescription: an official in some sports who controls the game and makes sure the rules are being followed
word.entryExample: A tennis umpire sits on a tall chair.

word.entryDescription: quiet, modest and avoiding the attention of other people
word.entryExample: It's a surprise how such an unassuming character could become this successful comedian.

word.entryDescription: your mother or father's brother, or their sister's husband
word.entryExample: My uncle always remembers to send me a birthday card.

word.entryDescription: directly below or at a lower level than something else
word.entryExample: There's a mat on the floor, under the table.

word.entryDescription: likely to experience something bad, be damaged or harmed
word.entryExample: When a species of animal or plant is under threat from something, it is endangered.

word.entryDescription: not cooked for long enough, with the result that it is not ready to eat
word.entryExample: The authors emphasise the role of ingestion of raw or undercooked meat as a source of toxoplasma infection.

word.entryDescription: a railway system in which electric trains travel below the ground in a city
word.entryExample: I like travelling by underground, because it's very quick.

word.entryDescription: below the surface of the earth
word.entryExample: The naked mole rat lives in underground tunnels in East Africa.

word.entryDescription: the small items worn under your other clothes
word.entryExample: We're going for a week so make sure you bring enough underwear.

word.entryDescription: not having a job
word.entryExample: He's been long-term unemployed and on benefits most of his life and he thinks getting money for nothing is great.

word.entryDescription: the state of not having a job
word.entryExample: Youth unemployment is a big problem in our country.

word.entryDescription: that you do not know or recognize; not frequently seen or experienced
word.entryExample: His face was unfamiliar.

word.entryDescription: used when a particular situation or fact makes you sad or disappointed
word.entryExample: Unfortunately, Maria felt sick.

word.entryDescription: with no furniture
word.entryExample: The apartment we rented was unfurnished.

word.entryDescription: in poor condition
word.entryExample: If you lead an unhealthy lifestyle, you're going to be more at risk of heart attack, diabetes and cancer.

word.entryDescription: dirty, unhealthy
word.entryExample: Many animals are dirty and unhygienic to have in the house.

word.entryDescription: particular clothes worn by everyone in an organisation
word.entryExample: Harry is wearing a school uniform.

word.entryDescription: not similar to anything else
word.entryExample: My sister's job is quite unique – she works as a trainer for animals that appear in films.

word.entryDescription: a course of study at a university, or the qualification that is given to you when you have successfully completed the course
word.entryExample: My brother has just finished his university degree.

word.entryDescription: not kind or friendly
word.entryExample: I hate people who are childish and unkind or unfriendly.

word.entryDescription: except if
word.entryExample: We will climb the Sydney Harbour bridge unless it rains or is too windy.
Unluckily, there wasn't any information on the internet.

word.entryDescription: that cannot be remembered, e.g. because it was not special; not worth remembering
word.entryExample: His face was unmemorable.

word.entryDescription: not good to taste
word.entryExample: If you’re stranded in the rainforest you have to make do with whatever food is available, no matter how unpalatable.

word.entryDescription: unable to be trusted to do something or be true; not reliable
word.entryExample: Don't ask Susan for a favour because she's really unreliable.

word.entryDescription: not satisfactory; not good enough
word.entryExample: Her performance in mathematics was particularly unsatisfactory.

word.entryDescription: not sociable; not enjoying the company of other people
word.entryExample: I'm being quite unsociable sometimes.

word.entryDescription: not damaged or changed in any way
word.entryExample: I can't think of a better combination of vibrant city life and unspoilt natural beauty.

word.entryDescription: not stable; likely to change suddenly
word.entryExample: Landslides can happen when the ground is highly unstable.

word.entryDescription: up to that time
word.entryExample: We are going to save our money until we have enough for a holiday.

word.entryDescription: to relax and become free of stress or worry, particularly after a period of stressful or hard work
word.entryExample: I can't wait to go on holiday and unwind on the beach with a good book!

word.entryDescription: towards a higher place
word.entryExample: The bird is flying up to the top of the tree.

word.entryDescription: positive and enthusiastic; optimistic
word.entryExample: What I liked most was the trendy, upbeat atmosphere – it had a fun, modern feel, with a DJ playing live music.

word.entryDescription: to copy or move computer data from a smaller device onto a larger system or network
word.entryExample: Mark uploaded his photos yesterday.

word.entryDescription: computer data that have been copied or moved or the proces of copying or moving them
word.entryExample: Before September I didn’t know what an upload or cloud computing were.

word.entryDescription: towards or in a higher part of the building
word.entryExample: Go upstairs to bed.

word.entryDescription: relating to cities and towns
word.entryExample: Crime is a greater problem in urban areas than in rural ones.
